summary: This is an amended notification letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida to a victim's attorney, informing the victim of the defendant's guilty plea and sentence in state court, and outlining the terms of a deferred federal prosecution agreement. It details the appointment of a special master-selected attorney for victims' civil litigation and the defendant's obligations regarding legal fees and waivers in potential civil suits under 18 U.S.C. ยง 2255.

persons.name: Robert Josefsberg
persons.context: Selected by an independent Special Master to represent victims in civil litigation against the defendant; his services are to be provided at no cost to the victim as the defendant is obligated to pay his fees.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.context: Signatory of the letter as the United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, notifying the victim's attorney of the case developments and agreements.

connections.description: Acosta's office is notifying the victim's attorney about Josefsberg's role as the special master-appointed attorney for victims in civil litigation.

events.title: Defendant's Guilty Plea and Sentencing
events.description: The defendant entered a guilty plea to violations of Florida statutes and was sentenced to twelve months' imprisonment, followed by six months' imprisonment, then twelve months of Community Control with conditions of community confinement.

keyFacts: The defendant pleaded guilty and was sentenced in state court on June 30, 2008, leading to a deferred federal prosecution agreement.
An independent Special Master selected Robert Josefsberg as the attorney representative for victims in civil litigation against the defendant, with the defendant obligated to pay Josefsberg's fees.
The defendant agreed not to contest jurisdiction, liability, or damages up to an agreed amount in any civil suit filed under 18 U.S.C. ยง 2255, provided the victim waives all other claims.
The letter references prior litigation between the United States and two other victims (Jane Does 1 and 2) regarding disclosure of the full agreement between the U.S. and the defendant.
The U.S. Attorney's Office explicitly states it cannot assist in civil litigation, underscoring the separation between the criminal prosecution and potential civil actions.
